Fat free milk

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎05-09-2012 07:26 AM

Why is fat-free milk considered a superfood, when it's simply sugar water. I would think that since all the fat is removed along with all the nutrients, it would be too high in glucose (sugar) and too low in nutrients to be acceptable, much less a superfood. I don't see how drinking fat-free vitamin-D fortified milk is any different from taking a vitamin-D supplement and drinking a glass of sugar water. 

 

Vitamin-D is very important, but it's not naturally occuring in milk and fat-free milk would keep the body from absorbing it.

Report Inappropriate Content

Re: Fat free milk

‎05-09-2012 03:08 PM - edited ‎05-10-2012 12:11 AM

There are approximately the same number of carbs (12g per cup) in fat free milk as regular milk.  Only the saturated animal fat is removed (which I think is a good thing).  The fat free milk would still have the protein and calcium and, as far as I know -- vitamin D.  But we may still calcium supplements, because the vitamin D in milk may not be enough, unless we drink too much of it.  With diabetes, we have to be careful to control the carbs and have the portions that we can handle.  The amounts that we can handle and work into our meal plans will be different for all of us.  Please tell us where you found that nutrients are removed from fat free milk, and that fat free milk keeps body from absorbing vitamin D.  The label on my skim milk from Krogers says it contains these percentages of Recommended Dietary Allowances:  Vit. C: 4%, Vit. A; 10%, Vit. D: 25%, and Calciuum: 30%.  I would guess that if someone has a vitamin D deficiency or needs extra vitamin D for some reason, they would need to take extra vit. D supplements.  But I don't think this milk is intended to supply everything from A to Z -- but rather to be somewhat supplemental.  A well-balanced diet would supply other essential nutrients, as well, although milk does have quite a bit, which is probably what put it on the superfoods list.

Nancy ~ T2 since '98 ~ 17 yrs ~ D&E 11yrs ~ treadmill, elliptical, bike 15-20 minutes 2-3x/day (includes evenings), dumbbells/strength-training, small portions heart-healthy high-fiber/low-fat fuel/carb-counting, modified Mediterranean/semi-vegetarian plant-based diet; 500mg Glucophage XR x4, 5mg Glipizide ER x4, 4000IU Vit. D/day ~ RHR 55 ~ Between 5.9-6.9 A1cs, av. 6.5

you can eat NO carbs and live a fine healthy life.

In the USA T2 1986, insulin 2000, T1 08, Omnipod pump 5/13

‎05-11-2012 05:09 PM

powerwalker2 wrote:

......................The label on my skim milk from Krogers says it contains these percentages of Recommended Dietary Allowances:  Vit. C: 4%, Vit. A; 10%, Vit. D: 25%, and Calciuum: 30%.  ....................

 

 

I got that from hubby's jug of skim milk, although I do put a little of it in my morning coffee.  I was looking at my cartons of unsweetened soy milk (4g carbs per cup) and unsweetened Almond Milk (2g carbs per cup) last night, and saw that they also have approx. the same amount of vitamins in them, in case anyone is interested.  I love milk, and have always drunk milk, but gradually switched a few years ago to soy milk to get fewer carbs, and now am also enjoying even fewer carbs with a little almond milk, too.  I only use them in my morning cereal, and now cut the carbs in half by measuring half cup of any of the above with a half cup of water.  It's still white like milk and still tastes the same.  I have gotten used to it. 

Nancy ~ T2 since '98 ~ 17 yrs ~ D&E 11yrs ~ treadmill, elliptical, bike 15-20 minutes 2-3x/day (includes evenings), dumbbells/strength-training, small portions heart-healthy high-fiber/low-fat fuel/carb-counting, modified Mediterranean/semi-vegetarian plant-based diet; 500mg Glucophage XR x4, 5mg Glipizide ER x4, 4000IU Vit. D/day ~ RHR 55 ~ Between 5.9-6.9 A1cs, av. 6.5

Re: Fat free milk

‎05-11-2012 06:46 PM

I like milk,in my cereal and other types of breakfasts like fruit and yogert. I slowly switched from whole milk(4%), to 2%, to 1%, to fat free. It is thin but I am used to it now. I have high cholesterol and triglycerides, so anything I can do to lower my fat intake is a good thing. If one eats a variety of food, you will consume carbs, proteins, fats and minerals. If one is careful, one can consume enough of the right ones but avoid over doing to wrong ones. But you have to be very careful and it is very hard. Exercise I beleive is the great equalizer. If one over eats on some carbs, it can be reversed with enough exercise. So by drinking fat free milk, I have reduced my fat intake by X # of grams of fat. If I am going to eat fat I use olive oil, grape seed oil and rice bran oil to get the right type of fats. We can not exist with out some fats, carbs, proteins etc.,but it is surprising to find out how little of each we really need.

Cogito ergo sum

‎05-11-2012 06:56 PM

to me that's going to extremes. But if it works for you and you can continue with it great. In my coffee i tried different milk types and they all just seem to water down my coffee. i make real strong coffee and use sugar free  coffee mate or int'l delight. They have no sugar, no carbs only 1 gram of fat, and 15 calories per 1/2oz. Yes I know they have lots of artificial stuff in them , but i only use it once per day with morning coffee and isn't everything a trade off really. There is no perfect system from where I can see.

Cogito ergo sum

‎05-11-2012 08:51 PM

odehealth wrote:

Why is fat-free milk considered a superfood, when it's simply sugar water. I would think that since all the fat is removed along with all the nutrients, it would be too high in glucose (sugar) and too low in nutrients to be acceptable, much less a superfood. I don't see how drinking fat-free vitamin-D fortified milk is any different from taking a vitamin-D supplement and drinking a glass of sugar water. 

 

Vitamin-D is very important, but it's not naturally occuring in milk and fat-free milk would keep the body from absorbing it.

 

It is neither a superfood nor particularly good for us. I include whole milk and pure cream in my menu in moderation.

 

As to "Why is fat-free milk considered a superfood?"; that is part of the out-dated but stil dispensed low-fat mantra espoused by the ADieteticA which goes right back to Ancel Keyes discredited experiments.

Cheers, Alan, Type 2, d&e metformin 2000mg, Australia.
Everything in Moderation - Except Laughter.
There is nothing I could eat I like more than my eyes.
Type 2 Diabetes - A Personal Journey(latest: Fat: The New Health Paradigm)
Born Under a Wandering Star (Latest: Ella to Kandy, Sri Lanka)

‎05-11-2012 09:23 PM

well since I have no insurance and no job and am disabled with diabetic nerve pain + a host of other things that are all painful, everthing I do has to take cost as the primary. I am able to get only 100 test strips/monthe for $15.00, which is a good deal, but if I want more it would be $60.00 /100. So testing more than 3 X per day is out of the question. The best method and a way to save ones fingers is a glucose continuous monitor which I  did a trial on about 5-6 years ago. It is semi-permenantly attached with a needle and tube into your stomach fat area, and records your BS every 5 minutes. Worked great when doing the free trial but the cost was out of site($1200.00). Any way I have reduced my A1c from 9.4 to 6.6 in the last 9 months , but taking a lot of insulin now to do it. Prior to that was just taking oral meds which had mostly stopped working. Still waiting for a cure , when someone will figure out how to stimulate those beta cells to reproduce and make more and better human go juice( insulin) LOL!

Cogito ergo sum
